string.text: Borz

The Borz ("Wolf") initially referred to a clone of the Armenian K6-92, however it has become an umbrella term applied to all improvised submachine guns produced during the years of independence of the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria. Only a few hundred Borzes were crafted at the "Krasniy Molot" plant, because production at this plant was stopped by the First Chechen War and moved into underground workshops. They are typically crude and inexpensive, with simple blowback operation, resulting in high rates of fire and low accuracy. The gun has fairly low durability, and may be best suited as a semi-disposable weapon, used to ambush and acquire higher quality guns from those that are better equipped.\n %c[ui_gray_2]ATTACHMENTS:\n %c[d_purple]• %c[ui_gray_2] 9x19 compatible suppressor
Duplet

The Duplet is an improvised double-barreled shotgun manufactured by technicians in workshops near and in The Zone. It was produced by first stalkers in The Zone, since the black market of firearms was almost non-existent back then. Currently the Duplets are increasingly less common as more weaponry is available for cheap from traders and arms smugglers. It is a simple, crude firearm made from reinforced scrap metal and wood, with two barrels placed horizontally. The accuracy is low due to crude finish of the inside of the barrel, but it's not an issue since the gun is made for point-blank ranges. Two barrels hold one shell each and can be fired both in the same time. Due to questionable construction, unless one is very careful with the trigger, the weapon has a tendency to shoot both barrels at once.
Springfield M1903A1 Marine Sniper

The Springfield M1903 is an American bolt-action rifle originally chambered in .30-06 Springfield, serving as the US military service rifle before it was replaced by the famed M1 Garand. It was adopted in 1903 and fought in both World Wars, seeing use among the USMC in WWII due to an insufficient supply of Garands. It also saw use as sniper rifle, equipped with 2.5x or 8x scopes until the early Vietnam war. Two sniper variants were made, the M1903A1 "Marine" with 7.8x Unertl scope and M1903A4 with 2.5x scope. The Marine variant is considered to be a much better rifle, not only due to its high-power optic, but also its high quality finish and superior accuracy. Today Springfield rifles are used as target or hunting rifles all around the world. In Europe Springfields are very rare, nonetheless they are sometimes seen.
 This specimen was rechambered to .308 Winchester likely as .308 ammunition is cheaper and easier to obtain.
 %c[ui_gray_2]ATTACHMENTS:
 %c[d_purple]• %c[ui_gray_2] Unertl 7.8x magnification scope (integrated)
M14 DMR

The US Marine Corps Designated Marksman Rifle (DMR) is a semi-automatic sniper rifle adapted from the M14 rifle, similar to the M21 rifle of US Army. The differences from the M14 are an accurized match barrel, special synthetic stock with pistol grip, RIS rail for mounting optics and Harris bipod. The M14 is an American battle rifle chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO, which for a short time served as a service rifle of US military. Experiences of WWII showed a need for improvements over the M1 Garand rifle, with characteristics including higher capacity, modern ammunition and lighter weight. The M14 was meant to replace several weapon types, however, this proved to be an impossible task. The M14 was deemed "completely inferior" to the M1 Garand in a 1962 report by the Department of Defense comptroller, eventually being replaced by the M16. M14s with scopes are popular among hunters and sport marksmen. Few military M14 DMR rifles reached The Zone, where they are liked for very good optical sights, providing much better precision than low-power scopes of SVD rifles.\n %c[ui_gray_2]ATTACHMENTS:\n %c[d_purple] • %c[ui_gray_2] Leupold 3-9x36 scope (integrated)
PPSh-41 (stick)

A major infantry weapon of the Soviet armed forces during World War II, the PPSh-41 was a durable, low-maintenance weapon made of cheap, easily-obtained components. They utilise 7.62x25mm cartridge. This gun is equipped with a 35 round stick magazine and fires at a healthy 1000 rpm.

Ruger Redhawk .45 ACP/.45 Colt

The Ruger Redhawk is a DA/SA, large-frame revolver that was first introduced in 1979 by Sturm Ruger and Company. Made from high-grade steel, it is available in a stainless steel finish. The Redhawk is reinforced to handle extra stress of high-pressure loads, making it very popular for use by handloaders as it is able to handle the most powerful .45 Colt and .44 Magnum loads easily. This model was designed to fire both .45 Long Colt and .45 ACP, though the rarity of .45 Colt in the zone has led .45 ACP to become dominant, however, due to the cartridge's shorter length it somewhat reduces the gun's accuracy.\n %c[ui_gray_2]COMPATIBLE MOD KITS:\n %c[d_purple] • %c[ui_gray_2] Default: Specialized weapon mod kit
Ruger Redhawk .357 (scoped)

The Ruger Redhawk is a DA/SA, large-frame revolver that was first introduced in 1979 by Sturm Ruger and Company. Made from high-grade steel, it is available in a stainless steel finish. The Redhawk is reinforced to handle extra stress of high-pressure loads, making it very popular for use by handloaders as it is able to handle the most powerful .45 Colt and .44 Magnum loads easily.\n This model is chambered in the common .357 magnum cartridge and features a low power integrated scope.
Smith and Wesson SW500 (modified)

The Smith and Wesson Model 500 is a five-shot, double/single action large-bore revolver originally firing the .500SW Magnum cartridge - the most powerful handgun cartridge in existence. The advanced design of the firearm helps in counteracting the recoil felt by the shooter. This includes the sheer weight of the firearm, use of rubber grips, the forward balance, and the use of a compensator. Nonetheless, the gun produces immense recoil.\n Due to the rarity of .500SW Magnum in the zone, ambitious gunsmiths have created modified copies, taking inspiration from the Russian RSh-12 revolver and converting the weapon to fire the subsonic 12.7Ã—55mm STs-130 cartridge shared by the ASh-12.7. These modifications have reduced the weapon's durability and lowered its potency, but the gun retains overwhelming power.
Serbu Super-Shorty

The Serbu Super-Shorty is a compact, stockless, 12 gauge pump-action shotgun. This one is based on a Mossberg 500 receiver and features a spring-loaded, folding foregrip. The Super-shorty is a shotgun that is used exclusively for personal defense, as it doesn't have enough range and velocity to be used effectively for hunting. It can however deal very high damage in short range and bring down most attackers in one well placed shot. It is regarded as a very effective weapon against mutants who rely on ambushes and quick leaps to attack their victim. Most stalkers prefer cheaper double-barrel sawn-off shotguns for this task, but the Serbu Super-Shorty has better handling and slightly higher capacity.
Molot Vepr 7.62 (scoped)

The Vepr (Ukrainian: "Wild Boar") is a semi-auto civilian hunting rifle based on RPK light machine gun and produced by Molot factory from Russia. Veprs found their way to The Zone as Stalkers often took their hunting rifles there, instead of buying military weapons on black market. They are well liked and sometimes preferred over AKs due to their higher accuracy and range.
 This variant is chambered in 7.62x39mm.

Winchester Model 70 - 7.92

The Winchester 70 is a bolt action hunting rifle and one of the most common hunting rifles in the world. It has been held in high regard by shooters since it was introduced in 1936, earning the moniker "The Rifleman's Rifle". The action has some design similarities to Mauser designs and it is a development of the earlier Winchester Model 54. It is available in multiple calibers and variants. the rifle is usually fed by a non-detachable internal magazine, with capacity varying based on caliber. Most common chamberings allowing 5 rounds, though larger rounds can reduce this to 4 or 3. While original 7.92mm rifles are exceedingly rare, made only for testing purposes and by special order, some after market conversions do exist.\n %c[ui_gray_2]ATTACHMENTS:\n %c[d_purple]• %c[ui_gray_2] Leupold VX-II 3-9x variable magnification scope (integrated)
Winchester Model 1894

The Winchester Model 1894 rifle (also known as the Winchester 94 or Model 94) is a lever-action repeating rifle that became one of the most famous and popular hunting rifles of all time. It was designed by John Browning in 1894 and originally chambered to fire two metallic black powder cartridges, the .32-40 Winchester and .38-55 Winchester.\n This variant is chambered in .357 Magnum.
Zastava M92

The Zastava M92 is a carbine developed and manufactured by Serbian Zastava Arms. The M92 is a shortened version of the Zastava M70 assault rifle, which is a modified copy of the Soviet AKM assault rifle. Unlike most rifle rounds which would otherwise experience a loss of velocity out of a shorter barrel, the 7.62x39mm round loses very little velocity when compared to a full length barrel. This makes it an excellent round for short-barrel rifles. The short barrel of the M92 may not lose enough velocity to even make a considerable difference when compared to the M70.
 This example comes in its base state with lightened parts, making it more suitable for long expeditions.
